title: Relax, the Commonwealth has not defaulted
text:
"It is always better to offer clarity," Mr Nicholls said, "because in financial markets people can misinterpret things."

"Operationally this does not have any effect on the AOFM at all."

The competitive tender was for $1 billion worth of Treasury Notes maturing on January 24, 2020 - three months away.

There were 31 bids totalling $936 million received on a weighted average yield of 0.9263 per cent.

Given the current cash rate is 0.75 per cent the AOFM would have been surprised not to meet its target volume of $1 billion.

But it just wasn't enough to attract the appetitite and some say that could be because people didn't bother.

Pendal bond portfolio manager Tim Hext said the shortfall might have just been that people didn't have the available cash or that they weren't awake to the relative strong yield.

"I think this tender will see a few people wake up now," Mr Hext said, "I think this might mean the next one will be oversubscribed."

The AOFM said it always likes to maintain a precautionary liquid asset balance in excess of forecast needs at any point in time. The AOFM has been issueing more notes of late. On Thursday morning it also issued $500 million of Treasury notes with an April 24, 2020 maturity and all were taken up at a yield of 0.93 per cent.

Uncovered treasury notes might be a new thing in Australia but it happens elsewhere.

US Treasury has been under increasing pressure to keep buyers bidding for its new bonds.

A concern for the US Treasury is the decline in the bid-to-cover ratios in bond auctions since peaking in 2012.

The bid-to-cover ratio has fallen from above three times earlier this decade, to around 2.4 times currently.

Citi noted that there had been a higher incidence of 'tailing' since the Fed stepped back from quantitative easing. Tailing is when an auction yield rises above the prevailing market rate, indicating weak demand.
description: A $1 billion Treasury note tender on Thursday was undersubscribed for the first time ever.
